leukocyte_origin.formula: All leukocytes originate from haematopoietic stem cells in the bone marrow
leukocyte_origin.correct: Haematopoietic stem cells differentiate into myeloid progenitors (granulocytes, monocytes) and lymphoid progenitors (lymphocytes)

wrong.answer: Leukocytes originate in the thymus
wrong.error: Confusing site of origin with site of maturation
wrong.fix: All leukocytes originate in bone marrow; T cells migrate to thymus for maturation
wrong.action: Origin = bone marrow; Maturation = may occur elsewhere (thymus for T cells)

wrong.answer: Each leukocyte type has a different origin tissue
wrong.error: Not recognising common origin of blood cells
wrong.fix: All blood cells including leukocytes derive from haematopoietic stem cells in bone marrow
wrong.action: One stem cell type → all blood cell lineages

wrong.answer: Leukocytes are produced in lymph nodes
wrong.fix: Lymph nodes are sites of lymphocyte activation; production occurs in bone marrow
wrong.action: Production = bone marrow; Activation = lymph nodes and tissues

persistent.gap: Confusion about leukocyte origin and maturation sites
persistent.action: Draw haematopoiesis: stem cell → myeloid/lymphoid progenitors → specific cell types

neutrophils.formula: Neutrophils are the most abundant leukocytes and first responders to bacterial infection
neutrophils.correct: Neutrophils are phagocytic granulocytes that engulf bacteria and die quickly, forming pus

wrong.answer: Neutrophils are long-lived cells
wrong.fix: Neutrophils are short-lived (hours to days) and die after phagocytosing pathogens
wrong.action: Neutrophils = first responders, short-lived, form pus when they die

wrong.answer: Neutrophils primarily fight viral infections
wrong.fix: Neutrophils are most effective against bacteria and fungi; viral infections involve other cells
wrong.action: Neutrophils = anti-bacterial; NK cells and lymphocytes = anti-viral

wrong.answer: Neutrophils are agranulocytes
wrong.fix: Neutrophils are granulocytes with multi-lobed nuclei and granules containing antimicrobial enzymes
wrong.action: Neutrophils = granulocytes (with granules); Lymphocytes = agranulocytes

persistent.gap: Confusion about neutrophil characteristics and function
persistent.action: Remember: Neutrophils = most abundant, first responders, phagocytic, anti-bacterial, short-lived

eosinophils.formula: Eosinophils combat parasitic infections and are involved in allergic responses
eosinophils.correct: Eosinophils release toxic granule contents onto parasites too large to phagocytose and contribute to allergic inflammation

wrong.answer: Eosinophils are the most abundant leukocytes
wrong.fix: Eosinophils are relatively rare (1-4% of leukocytes); neutrophils are most abundant
wrong.action: Neutrophils = most abundant; Eosinophils = rare, specialised

wrong.answer: Eosinophils fight bacterial infections
wrong.fix: Eosinophils specialise in parasites (especially helminths) and allergic responses, not bacteria
wrong.action: Eosinophils = parasites + allergies; Neutrophils = bacteria

wrong.answer: Eosinophils phagocytose parasites
wrong.fix: Parasites are too large; eosinophils release toxic granules onto them externally
wrong.action: Eosinophils = degranulation onto parasites; Neutrophils = phagocytosis of bacteria

persistent.action: Eosinophils: parasites (too big to eat, so release toxins), allergies, granule release

mast_cells.formula: Mast cells reside in tissues and release histamine during allergic reactions and inflammation
mast_cells.correct: Mast cells have IgE receptors; when allergens cross-link IgE, mast cells degranulate releasing histamine

wrong.answer: Mast cells circulate in the blood
wrong.fix: Mast cells are tissue-resident; basophils are their circulating counterparts
wrong.action: Mast cells = tissues; Basophils = blood (similar function)

wrong.answer: Mast cells are activated by IgG antibodies
wrong.fix: Mast cells have receptors for IgE, not IgG; IgE mediates allergic responses
wrong.action: Mast cells + IgE = allergic response; IgG = other immune functions

wrong.answer: Mast cells only function in allergies
wrong.fix: Mast cells also contribute to inflammation, wound healing, and defence against pathogens
wrong.action: Mast cells: allergies + inflammation + wound healing + innate defence

persistent.gap: Incomplete understanding of mast cell function and location
persistent.action: Mast cells: tissue-resident, IgE receptors, histamine release, allergies + inflammation

monocytes_macrophages.formula: Monocytes circulate in blood and differentiate into macrophages or dendritic cells in tissues
monocytes_macrophages.correct: Macrophages are long-lived phagocytes that also present antigens and coordinate immune responses

wrong.answer: Monocytes and macrophages are different cell lineages
wrong.fix: Monocytes are blood cells that become macrophages when they enter tissues
wrong.action: Monocyte (blood) → Macrophage (tissue) = same lineage

wrong.answer: Macrophages only kill pathogens
wrong.fix: Macrophages also present antigens, produce cytokines, remove debris, and coordinate immunity
wrong.action: Macrophages: phagocytosis + antigen presentation + cytokine production

wrong.answer: Macrophages die quickly after phagocytosis
wrong.fix: Unlike neutrophils, macrophages are long-lived and can phagocytose multiple pathogens
wrong.action: Neutrophils = die after eating; Macrophages = survive and continue

persistent.gap: Confusion about monocyte-macrophage relationship and function
persistent.action: Track: Monocyte (blood) → Macrophage (tissue): phagocytosis, antigen presentation, long-lived

dendritic_cells.formula: Dendritic cells are professional antigen-presenting cells that activate T lymphocytes
dendritic_cells.correct: Dendritic cells sample antigens in tissues, migrate to lymph nodes, and present antigens on MHC to naive T cells

wrong.answer: Dendritic cells kill pathogens directly
wrong.fix: Dendritic cells focus on antigen presentation, not pathogen killing; they activate other cells to kill
wrong.action: Dendritic cells = presenters; Macrophages/Neutrophils = killers

wrong.answer: Dendritic cells stay in one location
wrong.fix: Dendritic cells migrate from tissues to lymph nodes to present antigens
wrong.action: DC pathway: tissue (sample antigen) → lymph node (present to T cells)

wrong.answer: Dendritic cells only present on MHC class I
wrong.fix: Dendritic cells present on both MHC I and II, and can cross-present to activate CD8+ T cells
wrong.action: DCs present on MHC I (CD8 activation) and MHC II (CD4 activation)

persistent.action: Dendritic cells: best antigen presenters, migrate to lymph nodes, activate naive T cells

natural_killer_cells.formula: Natural killer cells are innate lymphocytes that kill virus-infected and cancer cells
natural_killer_cells.correct: NK cells detect missing MHC I on target cells and induce apoptosis without prior sensitisation

wrong.answer: NK cells require prior exposure to function
wrong.fix: NK cells are innate - they kill without needing prior sensitisation, unlike T cells
wrong.action: NK cells = innate (immediate); T cells = adaptive (require priming)

wrong.answer: NK cells recognise specific antigens
wrong.fix: NK cells recognise stressed cells by detecting missing or altered MHC I, not specific antigens
wrong.action: NK cells detect missing self (MHC I); T cells recognise specific antigens

wrong.answer: NK cells are part of adaptive immunity
wrong.fix: Although lymphocytes, NK cells are innate immune cells with no antigen-specific receptors
wrong.action: NK cells = innate lymphocytes; B and T cells = adaptive lymphocytes

persistent.gap: Confusion about NK cell classification and mechanism
persistent.action: NK cells: innate lymphocytes, detect missing MHC I, kill infected/cancer cells, no prior sensitisation

lymphocytes.formula: B and T lymphocytes are adaptive immune cells with antigen-specific receptors
lymphocytes.correct: B cells produce antibodies; T cells include helpers (CD4+) that coordinate immunity and cytotoxic (CD8+) that kill infected cells

wrong.answer: B cells directly kill pathogens
wrong.fix: B cells produce antibodies that mark pathogens for destruction; they don't kill directly
wrong.action: B cells = antibody factories; Cytotoxic T cells = direct killers

wrong.answer: Helper T cells kill infected cells
wrong.error: Confusing helper and cytotoxic T cell roles
wrong.fix: Helper T cells (CD4+) coordinate immunity; Cytotoxic T cells (CD8+) do the killing
wrong.action: CD4+ = helpers/coordinators; CD8+ = killers

wrong.answer: All lymphocytes respond to the same antigen
wrong.fix: Each lymphocyte has unique receptors for specific antigens; only those matching respond
wrong.action: Millions of lymphocytes, each specific; only antigen-matching cells activate

persistent.gap: Confusion about lymphocyte subtypes and functions
persistent.action: B cells = antibodies; CD4+ T cells = helpers; CD8+ T cells = killers; each specific to one antigen
